events.text:
Made by Viridino Studios (@ViridinoStudios)

Mateus Ferreira - Programmer
Twitter: @BonzerKitten
E-mail: ferreiramoreiramateus@gmail.com

Wesley Andrade - Artist
Twitter: @andrart7
E-mail: wesleymatos1989@gmail.com

Made with the support of patrons on https://www.patreon.com/viridinostudios
The currently active controllable object, like the main soldier or a tank.

children.text: Setup the level by defining the first controllable object to be the main soldier.
Setup each tank by adjust the position of their parts (machine gun, in arrow, etc) and adding them as a child of the tank, so they always stay together.
Setup the player graphics by adding it as a child of its collider, so they always stay together.
Constantly scroll the camera towards the currently active controllable object, but using linear interpolation for a smoother result.
Shake the screen by changing the layout angle based on a "Duration" and "Strength" parameters.
Whether or not a directional input is being used.
Sum of both horizontal (left and right) inputs.
Sum of both vertical (up and down) inputs.
Exact direction both axis are pointing towards.
Toggle the input left on.
Toggle the input left off.
Toggle the input right on.
Toggle the input right off.
Toggle the input up on.
Toggle the input up off.
Toggle the input down on.
Toggle the input down off.
Constantly update all axis based on the previously received and stored input values.
Pick the currently active controllable object.
Move it left or right depending the value stored in the horizontal axis.
Perform a jump.
Some actions are exclusive to the pilot, so it's important to filter them by checking if the object type is appropriate.
If the player lands on a tank, enter it by attaching the player to the tank and changing the controllable the object.
Flash the tank by adjusting its luminosity.
Hide the arrow by fading it out.
Some actions are exclusive to tanks, so it's important to filter them by checking if the object type is appropriate.
Rotate the machine towards the axis angle, but only while there's input from the player.
Shoot bullets from the machine gun with slightly random positions to create spread.
Shoot a bullet from the cannon and shake the screen for a more impactful effect.
Leave the tank reverting the controllable object to its previous state.
Flash the tank by adjusting its luminosity.
Show the arrow by fading it in.
Is the pilot is moving horizontally, update its width (whether or not the player is mirrored) to match its current movement direction.
Update the pilot animations based on the actions it's currently performing.
Walk animation.
Idle animation.
Jump animation.
Fall animation.
Update the tank animations based on the actions it's currently performing.
Walk animation.
How far the next dust particle will be from the center of the tank.
Leave a trail of dust behind the tank while it's moving.
Idle animation.
Jump animation.
Constantly update the angle of each tank by casting a ray downwards and applying the surface normal angle to the tank itself, but only while it's on the ground.
Apply surface normal angle to tank.
Reset tank angle to zero.
If a harmful object collides with the ground, destroy the harmful object.
If a harmful object collides with a barricade, destroy the harmful object and damage the barricade, by flashing it and reducing its heath.
If after getting damaged the barricades heath is equal or lower than zero, destroy it while also a leaving a big explosion and shaking the screen for a very impactful effect.
When a harmful object is destroyed, spawn a small explosion on top of it.

actions.text: Also reset the explosion angle to zero, so it always look correct.

children.text: Constantly update the luminosity of a "Flash" object while the "Flash" tween animation is being played, resulting in a brighter or darker image..
Once any of the animations of particle is over, destroy it, so it doesn't cause any sort of CPU overload over time.
